latestVersion.citationRequirements: International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI); University of California, Davis; University of Georgia. 2017. Market Segmentation Strategies for the Dissemination of New Agricultural Production Technologies: Experimental Delivery of Laser Land Leveling to Farmers in Uttar Pradesh, India. Washington, DC: IFPRI. http://dx.doi.org/10.7910/DVN/RSL6LQ http://dx.doi.org/10.7910/DVN/RSL6LQ
latestVersion.disclaimer: IFPRI adheres to the principle of unrestricted public access to its own final research outputs and will make such outputs freely available. The Institute encourages the use of the "Market Segmentation Strategies for the Dissemination of New Agricultural Production Technologies: Experimental Delivery of Laser Land Leveling to Farmers in Uttar Pradesh, India" dataset; for detailed information on its use please to IFPRI' Intellectual Policy. The data files in this dataset are unit record or 'raw' data files. Information that would allow survey respondents to be identified has been deleted from the files, but all other information remains. IFPRI's decision not to alter the contents of the data files means that the user of these files will need to take care in handling missing observations, outliers, and violation s of logical consistency. The data are provided 'as is' and in no event shall IFPRI be liable for any damages resulting from use of the data. While great effort was taken to obtain high-quality data, the accuracy or reliability of the data is not guaranteed or warranted in any way.

fields.value: Market Segmentation Strategies for the Dissemination of New Agricultural Production Technologies: Experimental Delivery of Laser Land Leveling to Farmers in Uttar Pradesh, India

dsDescriptionValue.value: This dataset contains observations from 478 households interviewed in 2011 and 2012 as part of a study titled “Market segmentation strategies for the dissemination of new agricultural production technologies in India.” The data were collected as part of a demand elicitation exercise and randomized control trial of custom-hired laser land leveling services provided to study participants. The study was conducted in the Maharajganj, Gorakhpur, and Deoria districts of eastern Uttar Pradesh, India under the auspices of the Cereal Systems Initiative for South Asia (CSISA). These three districts represent the regional spectrum of productivity in rice–wheat cropping systems. From each district, eight villages were randomly selected from a population of villages that met specific criteria set forth in the publications noted above. In addition to household data on the study participants, the dataset contains information on 926 plots cultivated by the study participants. Aside from household survey data, this study also contains data from village, social network, and monitoring surveys.

publicationCitation.value: Lybbert, Travis J.; Magnan, Nicholas; Spielman, David J.; Bhargava, Anil, K..; Gulati, Kajal. 2018. Targeting technology to reduce poverty and conserve resources: Experimental provision of laser land leveling services to Indian farmers. Economic Development and Cultural Change.

Magnan, Nicholas; Spielman, David J.; Lybbert, Travis J.; Gulati, Kajal. 2015. Leveling with friends: Social networks and Indian farmers’ demand for agricultural custom hire services. Journal of Development Economics 116: 223-251.

Lybbert, Travis J.; Magnan, Nicholas; Bhargava, Anil, K..; Gulati, Kajal; Spielman, David J. 2012. Farmers’ heterogeneous valuation of laser land leveling in eastern Uttar Pradesh: An experimental auction to inform segmentation and subsidy strategies. American Journal of Agricultural Economics 95(2): 339–345.

fields.value: This study was undertaken as a contribution to the Cereal Systems Initiative for South Asia (CSISA) with financial support from the United States Agency for International Development (grant ID no. BFS-G-11-00002) and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation (grant ID no.’s OPP52303 and OPP1052535), and under the leadership of the International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center (CIMMYT) and International Rice Research Institute (IRRI).

contributorName.value: Spielman, David J. (International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI))
Lybbert, Travis J. (University of California, Davis)
Makhija, Simrin (International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI))
Singh, Vartika (International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI))

grantNumberAgency.value: United States Agency for International Development (USAID)

value: The three districts chosen for this study represent the regional spectrum of productivity in rice–wheat cropping systems in eastern Uttar Pradesh. Heads and co-heads of households were chosen from the population of households that (1) operated farms in the rice–wheat cropping system and were not consistently prone to flooding that would inhibit rice cultivation; (2) lived in a village with no less than 48 households but not larger than 400 households; and (3) lived in the village was not within a 10 km radius of any other research or extension activities operating in the area that involved laser land leveling or other resource-conserving technologies.

fields.value: From each district, eight villages were randomly selected to participate in the study provided they met the following criteria: (1) The villages shared a similar rice–wheat cropping system and were not consistently prone to flooding that would inhibit rice cultivation; (2) the population in each village was not less than 48 households but not larger than 400 households; and (3) the village was not within a 10 km radius of any other research or extension activities operating in the area that involved laser land leveling or other resource-conserving technologies.  Within each village, 20–24 farmers were randomly selected from a village census if they were cultivating plots of at least 0.2 acres, which is the minimum plot size on which laser land leveling (LLL) can be conducted. These farmers were then given the opportunity to bid non-competitively in a binding experimental auction for custom-hired LLL services. In 2011, farmers who bid at or greater than a randomly drawn price were then randomly assigned through a lottery to either receive the LLL custom-hired services at the drawn price, or not. In 2012, no lottery was conducted such that any farmer who bid at or greater than a randomly drawn price could then receive custom-hired LLL services.
